body.name: Firefly: A Japanese Historical Fiction Novel (Warrior Woman of the Samurai Book 1)

productInformation.name: Best Sellers Rank
productInformation.value: #2,331 Free in Kindle Store (See Top 100 in Kindle Store) #1 in Historical Chinese Fiction #1 in Historical Japanese Fiction #8 in Historical Mystery, Thriller & Suspense Fiction

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2024
reviews.reviewText: An era and history rarely written about in a way that is so fascinating and absorbing. I loved Keiko and felt I was next to her as she grew from an ignored middle child to a samurai. To learn about this culture, including its underworld was nothing short of amazing. I'm looking forward to book 2.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2019
reviews.reviewText: Would have given it 5 stars, but it had some very gratuitous, trashy sex in places, almost as if the author left the room and some hack snuck in and wrote a couple of really horrifically bad porn scenes. That accounts for for no more than 4% of the entire book.The rest of the book is so well written and so beautifully done with characters that you can relate to from the "get go".Feudal Japan was like the rest of the world in its treatment of women. They were chattel, to be used by their families and then by their husbands. It was rare that a woman or a a man ever really had a say in who they married.Many of the poorer women were sold into prostitution when they were just out of diapers.This book shows a past way of life for a "noble" woman of birth to go, but it was so rare, you could probably count on one hand how many made it happen.I'm moving on to the next one in the series.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Both exceptionally articulated point of view and a good introduction for those who have no understanding of this culture or time period.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Not quite what I expected
reviews.reviewText: This starts as a historical fiction set in Japan featuring a teenager as she grows into her own. I didn't find it compelling and struggled to pick it up after putting it down though the end was quite dramatic.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Incredible Storytelling and a powerful woman
reviews.reviewText: This wonderfully written book was easily one of the best stories I have ever read. It is based on true facts, and I appreciated being taught Japanese terms to better understand the main character, Keiko, and her world. FYI: There are some intimate terms and scenes described that are certainly not for children. The writing is sharp, passionate, and sensual. Keiko, a noblewoman in ancient Japan, had few choices for true happiness in life. I enjoyed reading how Keiko tried to find better ways to live. I eagerly away reading the next book in this remarkable series.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Give it a try if you appreciate historical fiction
reviews.reviewText: I was expecting to be disappointed because of all the < 3 star reviews, but honestly it was a pretty good read. The only qualm I had with it was how easy it was for the heroine to master fighting styles that take others a lifetime. Think the difference in training between Rey and obiwan in starwars.I appreciate the brother sister dynamics esp when the brother swooped in to claim credit for the eagle.I know a few people were appalled by the sex scenes but considering how non straightforward Japanese culture is, the words used felt appropriate.Overall I found it to be an enjoyable read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars An interesting protagonist, a fun world
reviews.reviewText: This is a novel. It is make believe. Prepare to suspend your disbelief. It takes place in Japan, during the Tokugawa Shogunate. That’s about the only time frame we get for the book.Keiko is the third child of her father and is not as beautiful nor as spoiled as her older sister. Her older brother is becoming Samurai and takes her along for the ride. She learns martial arts quickly, and soon is teaching the teacher. It’s a novel. Go with it.Yes, there is sex in the story. Some might consider it gratuitous, but from what I’ve read of Japanese stories, and what I’ve seen of Japanese movies, it happens.I think what grabbed me the quickest was the introduction to some of the Samurai women of old, in particular, Tomoe Gozen. I hope she shows up in future books.I enjoyed this story. It may not be historically accurate, but the key word is “novel.” A novel is a piece of fiction, it is made up, one reads it to escape one’s current world, if only for a few minutes, and for that, it was wonderful. If you want accurate history, get out of the fiction department.I have already downloaded Book 2.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Definitely five stars!
reviews.reviewText: If you like reading about other cultures, this book will be an interesting read. The book touches on the differences in classes, life styles and traditions of the Samurai Warriors. It's fast paced and at the end I was left with wondering what would happen next?

reviews.reviewTitle: A lot learned about early Japan
reviews.reviewText: The story is good, a bit sappy at times but very interesting g

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 5, 2022
reviews.reviewText: This is a great read, many historical facts. Can’t wait to read the next book. Transports you to another world, another time

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the Netherlands on May 18, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: Leuke serie maar midden in boek twee gestopt
reviews.reviewText: Eerst boek pakt je nog wel maar in boek 2 ben ik gestopt... niet voor mij.

The first book was very good. It was hard to put down. I am looking forward to the following books so I can remain in this world of adventure, love, lust and honor. This book features a strong female main character and the plot and character development was pleasingly well done.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 22, 2023
reviews.reviewText: The author has selected an interesting subject for this novel, the onna-bugeisha or female samurai, little known female warriors. It certainly prompted me to read more history on the subject. I only really noticed one mistake in use of English language which was “lied” rather than lay. Also what a shame authors insist on splitting books up into book 1,2,……ad infinitum, I find it really irritating. Otherwise I quite enjoyed the novel and may read the next one at some point.
